sp.p: Pardon me, Sir; more uneasiness has arisen than you are aware of. I am myself, at this instant, in a state of inexpressible embarrassment; Miss Sterling, I know, is extremely disconcerted too; and unless you will oblige me with the assistance of your friendship, I foresee the speedy progress of discontent and animosity through the whole family.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What the deuce is all this? I don't understand a single syllable.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: In one word then—it will be absolutely impossible for me to fulfill my engagements in regard to Miss Sterling.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: How, Sir John? Do you mean to put an affront upon my family? What! refuse to—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Be assured, Sir, that I neither mean to affront, nor forsake your family.—My only fear is, that you should desert me; for the whole happiness of my life depends on my being connected with your family by the nearest and tenderest ties in the world.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Why, did not you tell me, but a moment ago, that it was absolutely impossible for you to marry my daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: True.—But you have another daughter, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Who has obtained the most absolute dominion over my heart. I have already declared my passion to her; nay, Miss Sterling herself is also apprized of it, and if you will but give a sanction to my present addresses, the uncommon merit of Miss Sterling will no doubt recommend her to a person of equal, if not superior rank to myself, and our families may still be allied by my union with Miss Fanny.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p:
Mighty fine, truly! Why, what the plague do you make of us, Sir John? Do you come to market for my daughters, like servants at a statute-fair? Do you think that I will suffer you, or any man in the world, to come into my house, like the
Grand Signior, and throw the handkerchief first to one, and then to t'other, just as he pleases? Do you think I drive a kind of African slave-trade with them? and—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A moment's patience, Sir! Nothing but the excess of my passion for Miss Fanny shou'd have induced me to take any step that had the least appearance of disrespect to any part of your family; and even now I am desirous to atone for my transgression, by making the most adequate compensation that lies in my power.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Compensation! what compensation can you possibly make in such a case as this, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come, come, Mr. Sterling; I know you to be a man of sense, a man of business, a man of the world. I'll deal frankly with you; and you shall see that I do not desire a change of measures for my own gratification, without endeavouring to make it advantageous to you.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What advantage can your inconstancy be to me, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Sir.—You know that by the articles at present subsisting between us, on the day of my marriage with Miss Sterling, you agree to pay down the gross sum of eighty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Now if you will but consent to my waving that marriage—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I agree to your waving that marriage? Impossible, Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope not, Sir; as on my part, I will agree to wave my right to thirty thousand pounds of the fortune I was to receive with her.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Thirty thousand, d'ye say?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and accept of Miss Fanny with fifty thousand, instead of fourscore.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Fifty thousand— [pausing.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Instead of fourscore.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Why,—why,—there may be something in that.—Let me see; Fanny with fifty thousand instead of Betsey with fourscore—But how can this be, Sir John?—For you know I am to pay this money into the hands of my Lord Ogleby; who, I believe—between you and me, Sir John,—is not overstocked with ready money at present; and threescore thousand of it, you know, is to go to pay off the present incumbrances on the estate, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That objection is easily obviated.—Ten of the twenty thousand, which would remain as a surplus of the fourscore, after paying off the mortgage, was intended by his Lordship for my use, that we might set off with some little eclat on our marriage; and the other ten for his own.—Ten thousand pounds therefore I shall be able to pay you immediately; and for the remaining twenty thousand you shall have a mortgage on that part of the estate which is to be made over to me, with whatever security you shall require for the regular payment of the interest, 'till the principal is duly discharged.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Why—to do you justice, Sir John, there is something fair and open in your proposal; and since I find you do not mean to put an affront upon the family—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nothing was ever farther from my thoughts, Mr. Sterling.—And after all, the whole affair is nothing extraordinary—such things happen every day—and as the world has only heard generally of a treaty between the families, when this marriage takes place, nobody will be the wiser, if we have but discretion enough to keep our own counsel.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: True, true; and since you only transfer from one girl to the other, it is no more than transferring so much stock, you know.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The very thing.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Odso! I had quite forgot. We are reckoning without our host here. There is another difficulty—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You alarm me. What can that be?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I can't stir a step in this business without consulting my sister Heidelberg.—The family has very great expectations from her, and we must not give her any offence.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But if you come into this measure, surely she will be so kind as to consent—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I don't know that—Betsey is her darling, and I can't tell how far she may resent any slight that seems to be offered to her favourite niece.—However, I'll do the best I can for you.—You shall go and break the matter to her first, and by that time that I may suppose that your rhetorick has prevailed on her to listen to reason, I will step in to reinforce your arguments.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll fly to her immediately: you promise me your assistance?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ten thousand thanks for it! and now success attend me![going.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Harkee, Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Not a word of the thirty thousand to my sister, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh, I am dumb, I am dumb, Sir. [going.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: You remember it is thirty thousand.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To be sure I do.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: But Sir John!—one thing more. [Sir John returns.] My Lord must know nothing of this stroke of friendship between us.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Not for the world.—Let me alone! let me alone![offering to go.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: [holding him.]—And when every thing is agreed, we must give each other a bond to be held fast to the bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To be sure. A bond by all means! a bond, or whatever you please. [Exit hastily.

I should have thought of more conditions—he's in a humour to give me every thing—Why, what mere children are your fellows of quality; that cry for a plaything one minute, and throw it by the next! as changeable as the weather, and as uncertain as the stocks.—Special fellows to drive a bargain! and yet they are to take care of the interest of the nation truly!—Here does this whirligig man of fashion offer to give up thirty thousand pounds in hard money, with as much indifference as if it was a china orange.—By this mortgage, I shall have a hold on his Terrafirma, and if he wants more money, as he certainly will,—let him have children by my daughter or no, I shall have his whole estate in a net for the benefit of my family.—Well; thus it is, that the children of citizens, who have acquired fortunes, prove persons of fashion; and thus it is, that persons of fashion, who have ruined their fortunes, reduce the next generation to cits. [Exit.

div2.stage: Enter Mrs. Heidelberg, and Miss Sterling.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: This is your gentle-looking, soft-speaking, sweet-smiling, affable Miss Fanny for you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: My Miss Fanny! I disclaim her. With all her arts she never could insinuat herself into my good graces—and yet she has a way with her, that deceives man, woman, and child, except you and me, niece.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: O ay; she wants nothing but a crook in her hand, and a lamb under her arm, to be a perfect picture of innocence and simplicity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Just as I was drawn at Amsterdam, when I went over to visit my husband's relations.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p:
And then she's so mighty good to servants—pray, John, do this—pray, Tom, do that—thank
you, Jenny—and then so humble to her relations—to be sure, Papa!—as my Aunt pleases—my Sister knows best—But with all her demureness and humility she has no objection to be Lady Melvil, it seems, nor to any wickedness that can make her so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: She Lady Melville? Compose yourself, Niece! I'll ladyship her indeed:—a little creepin, cantin—She shan't be the better for a farden of my money. But tell me, child, how does this intriguing with Sir John correspond with her partiality to Lovewell? I don't see a concatunation here.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: There I was deceived, Madam. I took all their whisperings and stealing into corners to be the mere attraction of vulgar minds; but, behold! their private meetings were not to contrive their own insipid happiness, but to conspire against mine.—But I know whence proceeds Mr. Lovewell's resentment to me. I could not stoop to be familiar with my father's clerk, and so I have lost his interest.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: My spurrit to a T.—My dear child! [kissing her.]—Mr. Heidelberg lost his election for member of parliament, because I would not demean myself to be slobbered about by drunken shoemakers, beastly cheesemongers, and greasy butchers and tallow-chandlers. However, Niece, I can't help diffuring a little in opinion from you in this matter. My experunce and sagucity makes me still suspect, that there is something more between her and that Lovewell, notwithstanding this affair of Sir John—I had my eye upon them the whole time of breakfast.—Sir John, I observed, looked a little confounded, indeed, though I knew nothing of what had passed in the garden. You seemed to sit upon thorns too: but Fanny and Mr. Lovewell made quite another-guess sort of a figur; and were as perfet a pictur of two distrest lovers, as if it had been drawn by Raphael Angelo.—As to Sir John and Fanny, I want a matter of fact.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Matter of fact, Madam! Did not I come unexpectedly upon them? Was not Sir John kneeling at her feet, and kissing her hand? Did not he look all love, and she all confusion? Is not that matter of fact? And did not Sir John, the moment that Papa was called out of the room to the lawyermen, get up from breakfast, and follow him immediately? And I warrant you that by this time he has made proposals to him to marry my sister—Oh, that some other person, an earl, or a duke, would make his addresses to me, that I might be revenged on this monster!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Be cool, child! you shall be Lady Melvil, in spite of all their caballins, if it costs me ten thousand pounds to turn the scale. Sir John may apply to my brother, indeed; but I'll make them all know who governs in this fammaly.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: As I live, Madam, yonder comes Sir John. A base man! I can't endure the sight of him. I'll leave the room this instant. [disordered.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Poor thing! Well, retire to your own chamber, child; I'll give it him, I warrant you; and by and by I'll come, and let you know all that has past between us.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Pray do, Madam!— [looking back.]—A vile wretch![Exit in a rage.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your most obedient humble servant, Madam![bowing very respectfully.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir John![dropping a half-curtsy, and pouting.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Miss Sterling's manner of quitting the room on my approach, and the visible coolness of your behaviour to me, Madam, convince me that she has acquainted you with what past this morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I am very sorry, Sir John, to be made acquainted with any thing that should induce me to change the opinon, which I could always wish to entertain of a person of quallaty. [pouting.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: It has always been my ambition to merit the best opinion from Mrs. Heidelberg; and when she comes to weigh all circumstances, I flatter myself—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: You do flatter yourself, if you imagine that I can approve of your behaviour to my niece, Sir John.—And give me leave to tell you, Sir John, that you have been drawn into an action much beneath you, Sir John; and that I look upon every injury offered to Miss Betty Sterling, as an affront to myself, Sir John. [warmly.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I would not offend you for the world, Madam! but when I am influenced by a partiality for another, however ill-founded, I hope your discernment and good sense will think it rather a point of honour to renounce engagements, which I could not fulfil so strictly as I ought; and that you will excuse the change in my inclinations, since the new object, as well as the first, has the honour of being your niece, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I disclaim her as a niece, Sir John; Miss Sterling disclaims her as a sister, and the whole fammaly must disclaim her, for her monstrus baseness and treachery.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Indeed she has been guilty of none, Madam. Her hand and heart are, I am sure, entirely at the disposal of yourself, and Mr. Sterling.
And if you should not oppose my inclinations, I am sure of Mr. Sterling's consent, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Quite certain, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: [behind.] So! they seem to be coming to terms already. I may venture to make my appearance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: To marry Fanny?[Sterling advances by degrees.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: My brother has given his consent, you say?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: In the most ample manner, with no other restriction than the failure of your concurrence, Madam.— [sees Sterling.]—Oh, here's Mr. Sterling, who will confirm what I have told you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: What! have you consented to give up your own daughter in this manner, brother?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Give her up! no, not give her up, sister; only in case that you—Zounds, I am afraid you have said too much, Sir John. [apart to Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Yes, yes. I see now that it is true enough what my niece told me. You are all plottin and caballin against her.—Pray, does Lord Ogleby know of this affair?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I have not yet made him acquainted with it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: No, I warrant you. I thought so.—And so his Lordship and myself truly, are not to be consulted 'till the last.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What! did not you consult my Lord? Oh, fie for shame, Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay, but Mr. Sterling—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: We, who are the persons of most consequence and experunce in the two fammalies, are to know nothing of the matter, 'till the whole is as good as concluded upon. But his Lordship, I am sure, will have more generosaty than to countenance such a perceeding—And I could not have expected such behavour from a person of your quallaty, Sir John.—And as for you, brother—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but hear me, sister!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I am perfetly ashamed of you—Have you no spurrit? no more concern for the honour of our fammaly than to consent—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Consent?—I consent!—As I hope for mercy, I never gave my consent. Did I consent, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Not absolutely, without Mrs. Heidelberg's concurrence. But in case of her approbation—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, I grant you, if my sister approved.—But that's quite another thing, you know.— [to Mrs. Heidelberg.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Your sister approve, indeed!—I thought you know her better, brother Sterling!—What! approve of having your eldest daughter returned upon your hands, and exchanged for the younger?—I am surprized how you could listen to such a scandalus proposal.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I tell you, I never did listen to it.—Did not I say that I would be governed entirely by my sister, Sir John?—And unless she agreed to your marrying Fanny—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I agree to his marrying Fanny? abominable! The man is absolutely out of his senses.—Can't that wise head of yours foresee the consequence of all this, brother Sterling? Will Sir John take Fanny without a fortune? No.—After you have settled the largest part of your property on your youngest daughter, can there be an equal portion left for the eldest? No.—Does not this overturn the whole systum of the fammaly? Yes, yes, yes. You know I was always for my niece Betsey's marrying a person of the very first quallaty. That was my maxum. And, therefore, much the largest settlement was of course to be made upon her.—As for Fanny, if she could, with a fortune of twenty or thirty thousand pounds, get a knight, or a member of parliament, or a rich common-council-man for a husband, I thought it might do very well.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But if a better match should offer itself, why should not it be accepted, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: What! at the expence of her elder sister! Oh fie, Sir John!—How could you bear to hear of such an indignaty, brother Sterling?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I! nay, I shan't hear of it, I promise you.—I can't hear of it indeed, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p:
But you have heard of it, brother Sterling. You know you have; and sent Sir John
to propose it to me. But if you can give up your daughter, I shan't forsake my niece, I assure you. Ah! if my poor dear Mr. Heidelberg, and our sweet babes had been alive, he would not have behaved so.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Did I, Sir John? nay speak!—Bring me off, or we are ruined. [apart to Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, to be sure, to speak the truth—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: To speak the truth, I'm ashamed of you both. But have a care what you are about, brother! have a care, I say. The lawyers are in the house, I hear; and if every thing is not settled to my liking, I'll have nothing more to say to you, if I live these hundred years.—I'll go over to Holland, and settle with Mr. Vanderspracken, my poor husband's first cousin; and my own fammaly shall never be the better for a farden of my money, I promise you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I thought so. I knew she never would agree to it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, how unfortunate! What can we do, Mr. Sterling?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What! must our agreement break off, the moment it is made then?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: It can't be helped, Sir John. The family, as I told you before, have great expectations from my sister; and if this matter proceeds, you hear yourself that she threatens to leave us.—My brother Heidelberg was a warm man; a very warm man; and died worth a Plumb at least; a Plumb! ay, I warrant you, he died worth a Plumb and a half.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well; but if I—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p:
And then, my sister has three or four very good mortgages, a deal of money in the three percents. and old South-Sea annuities, besides large concerns in the Dutch and French funds.—The
greatest part of all this she means to leave to our family.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I can only say, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Why, your offer of the difference of thirty thousand, was very fair and handsome to be sure, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay, but I am even willing to—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, but if I was to accept it against her will, I might lose above a hundred thousand; so, you see, the ballance is against you, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But is there no way, do you think, of prevailing on Mrs. Heidelberg to grant her consent?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I am afraid not.—However, when her passion is a little abated—for she's very passionate—you may try what can be done: but you must not use my name any more, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Suppose I was to prevail on Lord Ogleby to apply to her, do you think that would have any influence over her?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I think he would be more likely to persuade her to it, than any other person in the family. She has a great respect for Lord Ogleby. She loves a lord.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll apply to him this very day.—And if he should prevail on Mrs. Heidelberg, I may depend on your friendship, Mr. Sterling?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I shall be glad to oblige you, when it is in my power; but as the account stands now, you see it is not upon the figures. And so your servant, Sir John. [Exit.

What a situation am I in!—Breaking off with her whom I was bound by treaty to marry; rejected by the object of my affections; and embroiled with this turbulent woman, who governs the whole family.—And yet opposition, instead of smothering, increases my inclination. I must have her. I'll apply immediately to Lord Ogleby; and if he can but bring
over the aunt to our party, her influence will overcome the scruples and delicacy of my dear Fanny, and I shall be the happiest of mankind. [Exit.

div2.head: SCENE I. A room.
div2.stage: Enter Sterling, Mrs. Heidelberg, and Miss Sterling.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: WHAT! will you send Fanny to town, sister?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: To-morrow morning. I've given orders about it already.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Positively.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: But consider, sister, at such a time as this, what an odd appearance it will have.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Not half so odd, as her behaviour, brother.—This time was intended for happiness, and I'll keep no incendaries here to destroy it. I insist on her going off to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I'm afraid this is all your doing, Betsey.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: No indeed, Papa. My aunt knows that it is not.—For all Fanny's baseness to me, I am sure I would not do, or say any thing to hurt her with you or my aunt for the world.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, Betsey!—I will have my way.—When she is packed off, every thing will go on as it should do.—Since they are at their intrigues, I'll let them see that we can act with vigur on our part; and the sending her out of the way shall be the purlimunary step to all the rest of my perceedings.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Well, but sister—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p:
It does not signify talking, brother Sterling, for I'm resolved to be rid of her, and I will.
—Come along, child! [to Miss Sterling]—The postshay shall be at the door by six o'clock in the morning; and if Miss Fanny does not get into it, why I will, and so there's an end of the matter. [bounces out with Miss Sterling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: One word more, brother Sterling!—I expect that you will take your eldest daughter in your hand, and make a formal complaint to Lord Ogleby of Sir John Melvil's behaviour.—Do this, brother; shew a proper regard for the honour of your fammaly yourself, and I shall throw in my mite to the raising of it. If not—but now you know my mind. So act as you please, and take the consequences. [Exit.

The devil's in the woman for tyranny—mothers, wives, mistresses, or sisters, they always will govern us.—As to my sister Heidelberg, she knows the strength of her purse, and domineers upon the credit of it.—"I will do this"—and "you shall do that"—and "you must do t'other, or else the fammaly shan't have a farden of"— [mimicking.]—So absolute with her money!—but to say the truth, nothing but money can make us absolute, and so we must e'en make the best of her.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What! Mademoiselle Fanny to be sent away!—Why?—Wherefore?—What's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Je ne scais pas.—I know noting of it.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
It can't be; it shan't be. I protest against the measure. She's a fine girl, and I had much rather that the rest of the family were annihilated
than that she should leave us.—Her vulgar father, that's the very abstract of 'Change-Alley—the aunt, that's always endeavouring to be a fine lady—and the pert sister, for ever shewing that she is one, are horrid company indeed, and without her would be intolerable. Ah, la petite Fanchon! she's the thing. Is n't she, Cant?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Dere is very good sympatie entre vous, and dat young lady, mi Lor.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll not be left among these Goths and Vandals, your Sterlings, your Heidelbergs, and Devilbergs—If the goes, I'll positively go too.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: In de same post-chay, mi Lor? You have no object to dat I believe, nor Mademoiselle neider too—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy foolish tongue, Cant. Does thy Swiss stupidity imagine that I can see and talk with a fine girl without desires?—My eyes are involuntarily attracted by beautiful objects—I fly as naturally to a fine girl—

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: As de fine girl to you, my Lor, ha, ha, ha; you fly togedre like un pair de pigeons.—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Like un pair de pigeons— [mocks him.]—Vousetes un sot, Mons. Canton—Thou art always dreaming of my intrigues, and never seest me badiner, but you suspect mischief, you old fool, you.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I am fool, I confess, but not always fool in dat, my Lor, he, he, he.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: He, he, he.—Thou art incorrigible, but thy absurdities amuse one—Thou art like my rappee here, [takes out his box.] a most ridiculous superfluity, but a pinch of thee now and then is a most delicious treat.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: You do me great honeur, my Lor.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: 'Tis fact, upon my Thou art properly my cephalick snuff, and art no bad medicine against megrims, vertigoes, and profound thinking—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Your flatterie, my Lor, vil make me too prode.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The girl has some little partiality for me, to be sure: but prithee, Cant, is not that Miss Fanny yonder?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: [looking with a glass.] En veritè, 'tis she, my Lor—'tis one of de pigeons,—de pigeons d'amour.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Don't be ridiculous, you old monkey. [smiling.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I am monkeè, I am ole, but I have eye, I have ear, and a little understand, now and den.—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Taisez vous bête!

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Elle vous attend, my Lor.—She vil make a love to you.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Will she? Have at her then! A fine girl can't oblige me more.—Egad, I find myself a little enjouée—come along, Cant! she is but in the next walk—but there is such a deal of this damned crinkum-crankum, as Sterling calls it, that one sees people for half an hour before one can get to them—Allons, Mons. Canton, allons donc!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: My dear Fanny, I cannot bear your distress; it overcomes all my resolutions, and I am prepared for the discovery.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: But how can it be effected before my departure?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p:
I'll tell you.—Lord Ogleby seems to entertain a visible partiality for you; and notwithstanding the peculiarities of his behaviour, I am sure that he is humane at the bottom. He is vain to an excess; but withall extremely good-natured, and would do any thing to recommend himself to a lady.—Do you open the whole affair of our marriage to him immediately. It will come with more irresistible persuasion
from you than from myself; and I doubt not but you'll gain his friendship and protection at once.—His influence and authority will put an end to Sir John's sollicitations, remove your aunt's and sister's unkindness and suspicions, and, I hope, reconcile your father and the whole family to our marriage.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Heaven grant it! Where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I have heard him and Canton since dinner singing French songs under the great walnut-tree by the parlour door. If you meet with him in the garden, you may disclose the whole immediately.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Dreadful as the task is, I'll do it.—Any thing is better than this continual anxiety.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: By that time the discovery is made, I will appear to second you.—Ha! here comes my Lord.—Now, my dear Fanny, summon up all your spirits, plead our cause powerfully, and be sure of success.— [going.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Ah, don't leave me!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Nay, you must let me.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Well; since it must be so, I'll obey you, if I have the power. Oh Lovewell!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Consider, our situation is very critical. To-morrow morning is fixt for your departure, and if we lose this opportunity, we may wish in vain for another.—He approaches—I must retire.—Speak, my dear Fanny, speak, and make us happy![Exit.
Good heaven, what a situation am I in! what shall I do? what shall I say to him? I am all confusion.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
To see so much beauty so solitary, Madam, is a satire upon mankind, and 'tis fortunate that one man has broke in upon your reverie for the credit of our sex.—I say one, Madam, for poor
Canton here, from age and infirmities, stands for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Noting at all, inteed.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Your Lordship does me great honour.—I had a favour to request, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: A favour, Madam!—To be honoured with your commands, is an inexpressible favour done to me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: If your Lordship could indulge me with the honour of a moment's—What is the matter with me?[aside.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The girl's confus'd—he!—here's something in the wind faith—I'll have a tete-a-tete with her—allez vous en![to Canton.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I go—ah, pauvre Mademoiselle! my Lor, have pitié upon de poor pigeone!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll knock you down Cant, if you're impertinent. [smiling.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Den I mus avay— [shuffles along.]—You are mosh please, for all dat. [Aside, and exit.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I shall sink with apprehension. [aside.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What a sweet girl!—she's a civiliz'd being, and atones for the barbarism of the rest of the family.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: My Lord! I— [She curtseys, and blushes.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: [addressing her.] I look upon it, Madam, to be one of the luckiest circumstances of my life, that I have this moment the honour of receiving your commands, and the satisfaction of confirming with my tongue, what my eyes perhaps have but too weakly expressed—that I am literally—the humblest of your servants.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I think myself greatly honoured, by your Lordship's partiality to me; but it distresses me, that I am obliged in my present situation to apply to it for protection.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
I am happy in your distress, Madam, because it gives me an opportunity to shew my zeal. Beauty to me, is a religion, in which I was born and
bred a bigot, and would die a martyr.—I'm in tolerable spirits, faith![aside.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: There is not perhaps at this moment a more distressed creature than myself. Affection, duty, hope, despair, and a thousand different sentiments, are struggling in my bosom; and even the presence of your Lordship, to whom I have flown for protection, adds to my preplexity.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Does it, Madam?—Venus forbid!—My old fault; the devil's in me, I think, for perplexing young women. [aside and smiling.] Take courage, Madam! dear Miss Fanny, explain.—You have a powerful advocate in my breast, I assure you—my heart, Madam—I am attached to you by all the laws of sympathy, and delicacy.—By my honour, I am.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Then I will venture to unburthen my mind.—Sir John Melvil, my Lord, by the most misplaced, and mistimed declaration of affection for me, has made me the unhappiest of women.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: How, Madam! Has Sir John made his addresses to you?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: He has, my Lord, in the strongest terms. But I hope it is needless to say, that my duty to my father, love to my sister, and regard to the whole family, as well as the great respect I entertain for your Lordship, [curtseying] made me shudder at his addresses.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Charming girl!—Proceed, my dear Miss Fanny, proceed!

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: In a moment—give me leave, my Lord!—But if what I have to disclose should be received with anger or displeasure—

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Impossible, by all the tender powers!—Speak, I beseech you, or I shall divine the cause before you utter it.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p:
Then, my Lord, Sir John's addresses are not only shocking to me in themselves, but are more
particularly disagreeable to me at this time, as—as— [hesitating.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: As what, Madam?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: As—pardon my confusion—I am intirely devoted to another.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: If this is not plain, the devil's in it— [aside.] But tell me, my dear Miss Fanny, for I must know; tell me the how, the when, and the where—Tell me—

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: My Lor, my Lor, my Lor!—

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Damn your Swiss impertinence! how durst you interrupt me in the most critical melting moment that ever love and beauty honoured me with?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I demande pardonne, my Lor! Sir John Melvil, my Lor, sent me to beg you to do him the honour to speak a little to your Lorship.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: I'm not at leisure—I'm busy—Get away, you stupid old dog, you Swiss rascal, or I'll—

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Fort bien, my Lor.— [Cant. goes out tiptoe.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: By the laws of gallantry, Madam, this interruption should be death; but as no punishment ought to disturb the triumph of the softer passions, the criminal is pardoned and dismissed—Let us return, Madam, to the highest luxury of exalted minds—a declaration of love from the lips of beauty.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: The entrance of a third person has a little relieved me, but I cannot go thro' with it—and yet I must open my heart with a discovery, or it will break with its burthen.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: What passion in her eyes! I am alarmed to agitation. [aside.]—I presume, Madam, (and as you have flattered me, by making me a party concerned, I hope you'll excuse the presumption) that—

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Do you excuse my making you a party concerned, my Lord, and let me interest your heart in my behalf, as my future happiness or misery in a great measure depend—

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Upon me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Upon you, my Lord. [sighs.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: There's no standing this: I have caught the infection—her tenderness dissolves me. [sighs.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: And should you too severely judge of a rash action which passion prompted, and modesty has long concealed—

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: [taking her hand.] Thou amiable creature—command my heart, for it is vanquished—Speak but thy virtuous wishes, and enjoy them.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I cannot, my Lord—indeed, I cannot—Mr. Lovewell must tell you my distresses—and when you know them—pity and protect me!— [Exit, in tears.

How the devil could I bring her to this? It is too much—too much—I can't bear it—I must give way to this amiable weakness— [wipes his eyes.] My heart overflows with sympathy, and I feel every tenderness I have inspired— [stifles the tear.] How blind have I been to the desolation I have made!—How could I possibly imagine that a little partial attention and tender civilities to this young creature should have gathered to this burst of passion! Can I be a man and withstand it? No—I'll sacrifice the whole sex to her.—But here comes the father, quite apropos. I'll open the matter immediately, settle the business with him, and take the sweet girl down to Ogleby-house to-morrow morning—But what the devil! Miss Sterling too! What mischief's in the wind now?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: My Lord, your servant! I am attending my daughter here upon rather a disagreeable affair. Speak to his Lordship, Betsey!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Your eyes, Miss Sterling—for I always read the eyes of a young lady—betray some little emotion—What are your commands, Madam?

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: I have but too much cause for my emotion, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I cannot commend my kinsman's behaviour, Madam. He has behaved like a false knight, I must confess. I have heard of his apostacy. Miss Fanny has informed me of it.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Miss Fanny's baseness has been the cause of Sir John's inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Nay, now, my dear Miss Sterling, your passion transports you too far. Sir John may have entertain'd a passion for Miss Fanny, but believe me, my dear Miss Sterling, believe me, Miss Fanny has no passion for Sir John. She has a passion, indeed, a most tender passion. She has opened her whole soul to me, and I know where her affections are placed. [conceitedly.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Not upon Mr. Lovewell, my Lord; for I have great reason to think that her seeming attachment to him, is, by his consent, made use of as a blind to cover her designs upon Sir John.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Lovewell! No, poor lad! She does not. think of him. [smiling.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Have a care, my Lord, that both the families are not made the dupes of Sir John's artifice and my sister's dissimulation! You don't know her—indeed, my Lord, you don't know her—a base, insinuating, persidious!—It is too much—She has been beforehand with me, I perceive. Such unnatural behaviour to me!—But since I see I can have no redress, I am resolved that some way or other I will have revenge. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: This is foolish work, my Lord▪

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I have too much sensibility to bear the tears of beauty.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: It is touching indeed, my Lord—and very moving for a father.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
To be sure, Sir!—You must be distrest beyond measure!—Wherefore, to divert your too exquisite
feelings, suppose we change the subject, and proceed to business.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: With all my heart, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: You see, Mr. Sterling, we can make no union in our families by the propos'd marriage.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: And very sorry I am to see it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Have you set your heart upon being allied to our house, Mr. Sterling?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: 'Tis my only wish, at present, my omnium, as I may call it.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Your wishes shall be fulfill'd.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Shall they, my Lord!—but how—how?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll marry in your family.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What! my sister Heidelberg?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: You throw me into a cold sweat, Mr. Sterling. No, not your sister—but your daughter.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: My daughter!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Fanny!—now the murder's out!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What you, my Lord?—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Yes—I, I, Mr. Sterling!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: No, no, my Lord—that's too much. [smiling.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Too much?—I don't comprehend you.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What, you, my Lord, marry my Fanny!—Bless me, what will the folks say?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Why, what will they say?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: That you're a bold man, my Lord—that's all.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Mr. Sterling, this may be city wit for ought I know—Do you court my alliance?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: To be sure, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Then I'll explain.—My nephew won't marry your eldest daughter—nor I neither—Your youngest daughter won't marry him—I will marry your youngest daughter—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What! with a younger daughter's fortune, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
With any fortune, or no fortune at all, Sir. Love is the idol of my heart, and the daemon interest sinks before him. So, Sir, as I said before,
I will marry your youngest daughter; your youngest daughter will marry me.—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Who told you so, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Her own sweet self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Yes, Sir: our affection is mutual; your advantage double and treble—your daughter will be a Countess directly—I shall be the happiest of beings—and you'll be father to an Earl instead of a Baronet.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: But what will my sister say?—and my daughter?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll manage that matter—nay, if they won't consent, I'll run away with your daughter in spite of you.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Well said, my Lord!—your spirit's good—I wish you had my constitution!—but if you'll venture, I have no objection, if my sister has none.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll answer for your sister, Sir. Apropos! the lawyers are in the house—I'll have articles drawn, and the whole affair concluded to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Very well: and I'll dispatch Lovewell to London immediately for some fresh papers I shall want, and I shall leave you to manage matters with my sister. You must excuse me, my Lord, but I can't help laughing at the match—He! he! he! what will the folks say?[Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What a fellow am I going to make a father of?—He has no more feeling than the post in his warehouse—But Fanny's virtues tune me to rapture again, and I won't think of the rest of the family.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I beg your Lordship's pardon, my Lord; are you alone, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I am not alone! I am in company, the best company.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I never was in such exquisite enchanting company since my heart first conceived, or my senses tasted pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Where are they, my Lord?[looking about.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: In my mind, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: What company have you there, my Lord?[smiling.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: My own ideas, Sir, which so croud upon my imagination, and kindle it to such a delirium of extasy, that wit, wine, musick, poetry, all combined, and each perfection, are but mere mortal shadows of my felicity.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I see that your Lordship is happy, and I rejoice at it.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: You shall rejoice at it, Sir; my felicity shall not selfishly be confined, but shall spread its influence to the whole circle of my friends. I need not say, Lovewell, that you shall have your share of it.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Shall I, my Lord?—then I understand you—you have heard—Miss Fanny has inform'd you—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: She has—I have heard, and she shall be happy—'tis determin'd.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Then I have reached the summit of my wishes—And will your Lordship pardon the folly?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: O yes, poor creature, how could she help it?—'Twas unavoidable—Fate and necessity.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: It was indeed, my Lord—Your kindness distracts me.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: And so it did the poor girl, faith.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: She trembled to disclose the secret, and declare her affections?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The world, I believe, will not think her affections ill placed.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: —[bowing.]— You are too good, my Lord.—And do you really excuse the rashness of the action?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: From my very soul, Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Your generosity overpowers me.— [bowing.]—I was afraid of her meeting with a cold reception.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.l: More fool you then.
Who pleads her cause with never-failing beauty,
Here finds a full redress. [strikes his breast.
sp.p: She's a fine girl, Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Her beauty, my Lord, is her least merit. She has an understanding—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Her choice convinces me of that.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: —[bowing.]— That's your Lordship's goodness. Her choice was a disinterested one.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: No—no—not altogether—it began with interest, and ended in passion.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, if you were acquainted with her goodness of heart, and generosity of mind, as well as you are with the inferior beauties of her face and person—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I am so perfectly convinced of their existence, and so totally of your mind touching every amiable particular of that sweet girl, that were it not for the cold unfeeling impediments of the law, I would marry her to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I would, by all that's honourable in man, and amiable in woman.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Marry her!—Who do you mean, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Miss Fanny Sterling, that is—the Countess of Ogleby that shall be.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I am astonished.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Why, could you expect less from me?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I did not expect this, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Trade and accounts have destroyed your feeling.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: No, indeed, my Lord. [sighs.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The moment that love and pity entered my breast, I was resolved to plunge into matrimony, and shorten the girl's tortures—I never do any thing by halves; do I, Lovewell?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: No, indeed, my Lord— [sighs.]—What an accident!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What's the matter, Lovewell? thou seem'st to have lost thy faculties. Why don't you wish me joy, man?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: O, I do, my Lord. [sighs.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: She said, that you would explain what she had not power to utter—but I wanted no interpreter for the language of love.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But has your Lordship considered the consequences of your resolution?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: No, Sir; I am above consideration, when my desires are kindled.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But consider the consequences, my Lord, to your nephew, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Sir John has considered no consequences himself, Mr. Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Mr. Sterling, my Lord, will certainly refuse his daughter to Sir John.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Sir John has already refused Mr. Sterling's daughter.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But what will become of Miss Sterling, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What's that to you?—You may have her, if you will.—I depend upon Mr. Sterling's cityphilosophy, to be reconciled to Lord Ogleby's being his son-in-law, instead of Sir John Melvil, Baronet. Don't you think that your master may be brought to that, without having recourse to his calculations? Eh, Lovewell!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But, my Lord, that is not the question.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Whatever is the question, I'll tell you my answer.—I am in love with a fine girl, whom I resolve to marry.
What news with you, Sir John?—You look all hurry and impatience—like a messenger after a battle.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
After a battle, indeed, my Lord.—I have this day had a severe engagement, and wanting your Lordship as an auxiliary, I have at last mustered
up resolution to declare, what my duty to you and to myself have demanded from me some time.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: To the business then, and be as concise as possible; for I am upon the wing—eh, Lovewell?[he smiles, and Lovewell bows.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I find 'tis in vain, my Lord, to struggle against the force of inclination.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Very true, Nephew—I am your witness, and will second the motion—shan't I, Lovewell?[smiles, and Lovewell bows.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your Lordship's generosity encourages me to tell you—that I cannot marry Miss Sterling.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I am not at all surpriz'd at it—she's a bitter potion, that's the truth of it; but as you were to swallow it, and not I, it was your business, and not mine—any thing more?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But this, my Lord—that I may be permitted to make my addresses to the other sister.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: O yes—by all means—have you any hopes there, Nephew?—Do you think he'll succeed, Lovewell?[smiles, and winks at Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I think not, my Lord. [gravely.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I think so too, but let the fool try.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Will your Lordship favour me with your good offices to remove the chief obstacle to the match, the repugnance of Mrs Heidelberg?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Mrs. Heidelberg▪—Had not you better begin with the young lady first? it will save you a great deal of trouble; won't it, Lovewell?— [smiles.]—but do what you please, it will be the same thing to me—won't it, Lovewell?— [conceitedly.]—Why don't you laugh at him?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I do, my Lord. [forces a smile.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And you Lordship will endeavour to prevail on Mrs. Heidelberg to consent to my marriage with Miss Fanny?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll go and speak to Mrs. Heidelberg, about the adorable Fanny, as soon as possible.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your generosity transports me.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Poor fellow, what a dupe! he little thinks who's in possession of the town. [aside.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And your Lordship is not offended at this seeming inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Not in the least. Miss Fanny's charms will even excuse infidelity—I look upon women as the ferae naturae,—lawfull game—and every man who is qualified, has a natural right to pursue them; Lovewell as well as you, and I as well as either of you.—Every man shall do his best, without offence to any—what say you, kinsmen?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You have made me happy, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And me, I assure you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: And I am superlatively so—allons donc—to horse and away, boys!—you to your affairs, and I to mine—suivons l'amour![sings.

div2.head: SCENE I. Fanny's apartment.
div2.stage: Enter Lovewell and Fanny—followed by Betty.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: WHY did you come so soon, Mr. Lovewell? the family is not yet in bed, and Betty certainly heard somebody listening near the chamber-door.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My mistress is right, Sir! evil spirits are abroad; and I am sure you are both too good, not to expect mischief from them.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But who can be so curious, or so wicked?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I think we have wickedness, and curiosity enough in this family, Sir, to expect the worst.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p:
I do expect the worst.—Prithee, Betty, return to the outward door, and listen if you hear
any body in the gallery; and let us know directly.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I warrant you, Madam—the Lord bless you both![Exit.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: What did my father want with you this evening?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: He gave me the key of his closet, with orders to bring from London some papers relating to Lord Ogleby.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: And why did not you obey him?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Because I am certain that his Lordship has open'd his heart to him about you, and those papers are wanted merely on that account—but as we shall discover all to-morrow, there will be no occasion for them, and it would be idle in me to go.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Hark!—hark! bless me, how I tremble!—I feel the terrors of guilt—indeed, Mr. Lovewell, this is too much for me.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And for me too, my sweet Fanny. Your apprehensions make a coward of me.—But what can alarm you? your aunt and sister are in their chambers, and you have nothing to fear from the rest of the family.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I fear every body, and every thing, and every moment—My mind is in continual agitation and dread;—indeed, Mr. Lovewell, this situation may have very unhappy consequences. [weeps.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p:
But it shan't—I would rather tell our story this moment to all the house, and run the risque of maintaining you by the hardest labour, than suffer you to remain in this dangerous perplexity.—What! shall I sacrifice all my best hopes and affections, in your dear health and safety, for the mean, and in such a case, the meanest consideration—of our fortune! Were we to be abandon'd by all our relations, we have that in our hearts and minds, will weigh against the most affluent circumstances.—I should not have propos'd the secrecy of our marriage, but for your sake; and with hopes that the
most generous sacrifice you have made to love and me, might be less injurious to you, by waiting a lucky moment of reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Hush! hush! for heav'n sake, my dear Lovewell, don't be so warm!—your generosity gets the better of your prudence; you will be heard, and we shall be discovered.—I am satisfied, indeed I am.—Excuse this weakness, this delicacy—this what you will.—My mind's at peace—indeed it is—think no more of it, if you love me!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: That one word has charm'd me, as it always does, to the most implicit obedience; it would be the worst of ingratitude in me to distress you a moment. [kisses her.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [in a low voice.] I'm sorry to disturb you.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Ha! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Have you heard any body?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have, and they have heard you too, or I am mistaken—if they had seen you too, we should have been in a fine quandary.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Prithee don't prate now, Betty!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: What did you hear?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I was preparing myself, as usual, to take me a little nap.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: A nap!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, a nap; for I watch much better so than wide awake; and when I had wrap'd this handkerchief round my head, for fear of the earach, from the key-hole I thought I heard a kind of a sort of a buzzing, which I first took for a gnat, and shook my head two or three times, and went so with my hand—

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Well—well—and so—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: And so, Madam, when I heard Mr. Lovewell a little loud, I heard the buzzing louder too—and pulling off my handkerchief softly—I could hear this sort of noise— [makes an indistinct noise like speaking.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Well, and what did they say?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh! I cou'd not understand a word of what was said.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: The outward door is lock'd?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes; and I bolted it too, for fear of the worst.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Why did you? they must have heard you, if they were near.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: And I did it on purpose, Madam, and cough'd a little too, that they might not hear Mr. Lovewell's voice—when I was silent, they were silent, and so I came to tell you.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Fear nothing; we know the worst▪ it will only bring on our catastrophe a little too soon—but Betty might fancy this noise—she's in the conspiracy, and can make a man of a mouse at any time.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I can distinguish a man from a mouse, as well as my betters—I am sorry you think so ill of me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: He compliments you, don't be a fool!—Now you have set her tongue a running, she'll mutter for an hour. [to Lovewell.] I'll go and hearken myself. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'll turn my back upon no girl, for sincerity and service. [half aside, and muttering.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Thou art the first in the world for both; and I will reward you soon, Betty, for one and the other.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'm not marcenary neither—I can live on a little, with a good carreter.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: All seems quiet—suppose, my dear, you go to your own room—I shall be much easier then—and to-morrow we will be prepared for the discovery.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You may discover, if you please; but, for my part, I shall still be secret. [half aside, and muttering.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p:
Should I leave you now,—if they still are upon the watch, we shall lose the advantage of our delay.—Besides, we should consult upon to-morrow's business,—Let Betty go to her own room, and lock
the outward door after her; we can fasten this; and when she thinks all safe, she may return and let me out as usual.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Shall I, Madam?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Do! let me have my way to-night, and you shall command me ever after.—I would not have you surprized here for the world.—Pray leave me! I shall be quite myself again, if you will oblige me.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I live only to oblige you, my sweet Fanny! I'll be gone this moment. [going.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Let us listen first at the door, that you may not be intercepted.—Betty shall go first, and if they lay hold of her—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: They'll have the wrong sow by the ear, I can tell them that. [going hastily.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Softly—softly—Betty! don't venture out, if you hear a noise.—Softly, I beg of you!—See, Mr. Lovewell, the effects of indiscretion!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But love, Fanny, makes amends for all.

head.stage: SCENE changes to a gallery, which leads to several bed-chambers.

div2.stage: Enter Miss Sterling, leading Mrs. Heidelberg in a night-cap.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: This way, dear Madam, and then I'll tell you all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Nay, but Niece—consider a little—don't drag me out in this figur—let me put on my fly-cap!—if any of my Lord's fammaly, or the counsellors at law, should be stirring, I should be perdigus disconcarted.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: But, my dear Madam, a moment is an age, in my situation. I am sure my sister has been plotting my disgrace and ruin in that chamber—O she's all craft and wickedness!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p:
Well, but softly, Betsey!—you are all in emotion—your mind is too much flustrated—you
can neither eat nor drink, nor take your natural rest—compose yourself, child; for if we are not as warysome as they are wicked, we shall disgrace ourselves and the whole fammaly.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: We are disgrac'd already, Madam—Sir John Melvil has forsaken me; my Lord cares for nobody but himself; or, if for any body, it is my sister; my father, for the sake of a better bargain, would marry me to a 'Change-broker; so that if you, Madam, don't continue my friend—if your forsake me—if I am to lose my best hopes and consolation—in your tenderness—and affect—ions—I had better—at once—give up the matter—and let my sister enjoy—the fruits of her treachery—trample with scorn upon the rights of her elder sister, the will of the best of aunts, and the weakness of a too interested father. [she pretends to be bursting into tears all this speech.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Don't Betsey—keep up your spurrit—I hate whimpering—I am your friend—depend upon me in every partickler—but be composed, and tell me what new mischief you have discover'd.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: I had no desire to sleep, and would not undress myself, knowing that my Machiavel sister would not rest till she had broke my heart:—I was so uneasy that I could not stay in my room, but when I thought that all the house was quiet, I sent my maid to discover what was going forward; she immediately came back and told me that they were in high consultation; that she had heard only, for it was in the dark, my sister's maid conduct Sir John Melvil to her mistress, and then lock the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: And how did you conduct yourself in this dalimma?

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p:
I return'd with her, and could hear a man's voice, though nothing that they said distinctly; and you may depend upon it, that Sir John is now in that room, that they have settled the matter, and
will run away together before morning, if we don't prevent them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Why the brazen slut! has she got her sister's husband (that is to be) lock'd up in her chamber! at night too?—I tremble at the thoughts▪

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Hush, Madam! I hear something.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: You frighten me—let me put on my fly cap—I would not be seen in this figur for the world.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: 'Tis dark, Madam; you can't be seen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I protest there's a candle coming, and a man too.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Nothing but servants; let us retire a moment![they retire.

div2.stage: Enter Brush half drunk, laying hold of the Chambermaid, who has a candle in her hand.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Be quiet Mr. Brush; I shall drop down with terror!

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: But my sweet, and most amiable chambermaid, if you have no love, you may hearken to a little reason; that cannot possibly do your virtue any harm.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: But you will do me harm, Mr. Brush, and a great deal of harm too—pray let me go—I am ruin'd if they hear you—I tremble like an asp.

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: But they shan't hear us—and if you have a mind to be ruin'd, it shall be the making of your fortune, you little slut, you!—therefore I say it again, if you have no love—hear a little reason!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: I wonder at your impurence, Mr. Brush, to use me in this manner; this is not the way to keep me company, I assure you.—You are a town rake I see, and now you are a little in liquor, you fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p:
Nothing, by heav'ns, but your frowns, most amiable chamber-maid; I am a little electrified, that's the truth on't; I am not used to drink Port, and
your master's is so heady, that a pint of it oversets a claret-drinker.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Don't be rude! bless me!—I shall be ruin'd—what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: I'll take care of you, by all that's honourable.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: You are a base man to use me so—I'll cry out, if you don't let me go—that is Miss Sterling's chamber, that Miss Fanny's, and that Madam Heidelberg's. [pointing.

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: And that my Lord Ogleby's, and that my Lady what d'ye call'em: I don't mind such folks when I'm sober, much less when I am whimsical—rather above that too.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: More shame for you, Mr. Brush!—you terrify me—you have no modesty.

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: O but I have, my sweet spider-brusher!—for instance, I reverence Miss Fanny—she's a most delicious morsel and fit for a prince—with all my horrors of matrimony, I could marry her myse;f—but for her sister—

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: There, there, Madam, all in a story!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Bless me, Mr. Brush!—I heard something!

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: Rats, I suppose, that are gnawing the old timbers of this execrable old dungeon—If it was mine, I would pull it down, and fill your fine canal up with the rubbish; and then I should get rid of two damn'd things at once.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Law! law! how you blaspheme!—we shall have the house upon our heads for it.

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: No, no, it will last our time—but as I was faying, the eldest sister—Miss Jezabel—

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Is a fine young lady for all your evil tongue.

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: No—we have smoak'd her already; and unless she marries our old Swiss, she can have none of us—no, no, she wont do—we are a little too nice.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: You're a monstrous rake, Mr. Brush, and don't care what you say.

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: Why, for that matter, my dear, I am a little inclined to mischief; and if you won't have pity upon me, I will break open that door and ravish Mrs. Heidelberg.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: [coming forward.] There's no bearing this—you profligate monster!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Ha! I am undone!

sp.speaker: Brush.
sp.p: Zounds! here she is, by all that's monstrous. [runs off.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: A fine discourse you have had with that fellow!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: And a fine time of night it is to be here with that drunken monster.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: What have you, to say for yourself?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: I can say nothing.—I am so frighten'd, and so asham'd—but indeed I am vartuous—I am vartuous indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Well, well—don't tremble so; but tell us what you know of this horrable plot here.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: We'll forgive you, if you'll discover all.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Why, Madam—don't let me betray my fellow servants—I shan't sleep in my bed, if I do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Then you shall sleep somewhere else to-morrow night.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: O dear!—what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Tell us this moment,—or I'll turn you out of doors directly.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Why our butler has been treating us below in his pantry—Mr. Brush forc'd us to make a kind of a holiday night of it.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Holiday! for what?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Nay I only made one.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Well, well; but upon what account?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Because, as how, Madam, there was a change in the family they said,—that his honour, Sir John—was to marry Miss Fanny instead of your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: And so you made a holiday for that.—Very fine!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: I did not make it, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: But do you know nothing of Sir John's being to run away with Miss Fanny to-night?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: No, indeed, Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Nor of his being now locked up in my sister's chamber?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: No, as I hope for marcy, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Well, I'll put an end to all this directly—do you run to my brother Sterling—

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Now, Ma'am!—'Tis so very late, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I don't care how late it is. Tell him there are thieves in the house—that the house is o'fire—tell him to come here immediately—go, I say!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: I will, I will, though I'm frighten'd out of my wits. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Do you watch here, my dear; and I'll put myself in order, to face them. We'll plot 'em, and counter-plot 'em too. [Exit into her chamber.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: I have as much pleasure in this revenge, as in being made a countess!—Ha! they are unlocking the door.—Now for it![retires.

div2.stage: Fanny's door is unlock'd—and Betty comes out with a candle. Miss Sterling approaches her.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [calling within.] Sir, Sir!—now's your time—all's clear. [seeing Miss Sterl.] Stay, stay—not yet—we are watch'd.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: And so you are, Madam Betty! [Miss Sterling lays hold of her, while Betty locks the door, and puts the key in her pocket.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [turning round.] What's the matter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Nay, that you shall tell my father and aunt, Madam.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am no tell-tale, Madam, and no thief they'll get nothing from me.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p:
You have a great deal of courage,
Betty; and considering the secrets you have to keep, you have occasion for it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My mistress shall never repent her good opinion of me, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What is all this? what's the matter? why am I disturbed in this manner?

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: This creature, and my distresses, Sir, will explain the matter.

div2.stage: Re-enter Mrs. Heidelberg, with another head-dress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Now I'm prepar'd for the rancounter—well, brother, have you heard of this scene of wickedness?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Not I—but what is it? Speak!—I was got into my little closet—all the lawyers were in bed, and I had almost lost my senses in the confusion of Lord Ogleby's mortgages, when I was alarm'd with a foolish girl, who could hardly speak; and whether it's fire, or thieves, or murder, or a rape, I am quite in the dark.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: No, no, there's no rape, brother!—all parties are willing, I believe.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Who's in that chamber?[detaining Betty, who seemed to be stealing away.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My mistress.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: And who is with your mistress?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why, who should there be?

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Open the door then, and let us see!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: The door is open, Madam. [Miss Sterling goes to the door.] I'll sooner die than peach![Exit hastily.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: The door's lock'd; and she has got the key in her pocket.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: There's impudence, brother! piping hot from your daughter Fanny's school!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: But, zounds! what is all this about? You tell me of a sum total, and you don't produce the particulars.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Sir John Melvil is lock'd up in your daughter's bed-chamber.—There is the particular!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: The devil he is?—That's bad!

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: And he has been there some time too.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ditto!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Ditto! worse and worse, I say. I'll raise the house, and expose him to my Lord, and the whole family.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: By no means! we shall expose ourselves, sister!—the best way is to insure privately—let me alone!—I'll make him marry her to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Make him marry her! this is beyond all patience!—You have thrown away all your affection; and I shall do as much by my obedience: unnatural fathers, make unnatural children.—My revenge is in my own power, and I'll indulge it.—Had they made their escape, I should have been exposed to the derision of the world:—but the deriders shall be derided; and so—help! help, there! thieves! thieves!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Tit-for-tat, Betsey!—you are right, my girl.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Zounds! you'll spoil all—you'll raise the whole family,—the devil's in the girl.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: No, no; the devil's in you, brother. I am asham'd of your principles.—What! would you connive at your daughter's being lock'd up with her sister's husband? Help! thieves! thieves! I say. [cries out.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Sister, I beg you!—daughter, I command you.—If you have no regard for me, consider yourselves!—we shall lose this opportunity of ennobling our blood, and getting above twenty per cent. for our money.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: What, by my disgrace and my sister's triumph! I have a spirit above such mean considerations; and to shew you that it is not a low-bred, vulgar 'Change-Alley spirit—help! help! thieves! thieves! thieves! I say.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you may save your lungs—the house is in an uproar;—women at best have no discretion; but in a passion they'll fire a house, or burn themselves in it, rather than not be revenged.

div2.stage: Enter Canton, in a night-gown and slippers.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Eh, diable! vat is de raison of dis great noise, this tintamarre?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ask those ladies, Sir; 'tis of their making.
Brush! Brush!—Canton! where are you?—What's the matter? [rings a bell.] Where are you?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: 'Tis my Lord calls, Mr. Canton.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I com, mi Lor!— [Exit Canton.] —[Lord Ogleby still rings.
A light! a light here!—where are the servants? Bring a light for me, and my brothers.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Lights here! lights for the gentlemen![Exit Sterling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: My brother feels, I see—your sister's turn will come next.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let it go round, Madam! it is the only comfort I have left.

div2.stage: Re-enter Sterling, with lights, before Serjeant Flower (with one boot and a slipper) and Traverse.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: This way, Sir! this way, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Serjeant Flower.
sp.p: Well, but, Mr. Sterling, no danger I hope.—Have they made a burglarious entry?—Are you prepar'd to repulse them?—I am very much alarm'd about thieves at circuit-time.—They would be particularly severe with us gentlemen of the bar.

sp.speaker: Traverse.
sp.p: No danger, Mr. Sterling?—No trespass, I hope?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: None, gentlemen, but of those ladies making.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p:
You'll be asham'd to know, gentlemen, that all your labours and studies about this
young lady are thrown away—Sir John Melvil is at this moment lock'd up with this lady's younger sister.

sp.speaker: Serjeant Flower.
sp.p: The thing is a little extraordinary, to be sure—but, why were we to be frighten'd out of our beds for this? Could not we have try'd this cause to-morrow morning?

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: But, Sir, by to-morrow morning, perhaps, even your assistance would not have been of any service—the birds now in that cage would have flown away.

div2.stage: Enter Lord Ogleby [in his robe de chambre, night cap &c.—leaning on Canton.]

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I had rather lose a limb than my night's rest—what's the matter with you all?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis all over!—Here's my Lord too.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What is all this shrieking and screaming?—Where's my angelick Fanny. She's safe, I hope!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Your angelick Fanny, my Lord, is lock'd up with your angelick nephew in that chamber.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: My nephew! then will I be excommunicated.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Your nephew, my Lord, has been plotting to run away with the younger sister; and the younger sister has been plotting to run away with your nephew: and if we had not watch'd them and call'd up the fammaly, they had been upon the scamper to Scotland by this time.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Look'ee, ladies!—I know that Sir John has conceiv'd a violent passion for Miss Fanny; and I know too that Miss Fanny has conceiv'd a violent passion for another person; and I am so well convinc'd of the rectitude of her affections, that I will support them with my fortune, my honour, and my life.—Eh, shant I, Mr. Sterling? [smiling] what say you?—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: [sulkily.] To be sure, my Lord.—These bawling women have been the ruin of every thing. [aside.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: But come, I'll end this business in a trice—if you, ladies, will compose yourselves, and Mr. Sterling will insure Miss Fanny from violence, I will engage to draw her from her pillow with a whisper thro' the keyhole.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: The horrid creatures!—I say, my Lord, break the door open.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Let me beg of your delicacy not to be too precipitate!—Now to our experiment![advancing towards the door.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Now, what will they do?—my heart will beat thro' my bosom.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: There's no occasion for breaking open doors, my Lord; we have done nothing that we ought to be asham'd of, and my mistress shall face her enemies.— [going to unlock the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: There's impudence.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The mystery thickens. Lady of the bed-chamber! [to Betty] open the door, and intreat Sir John Melvil (for these ladies will have it that he is there,) to appear and answer to high crimes and misdemeanors.—Call Sir John Melvil into the court!

div2.stage: Enter Sir John Melvil, on the other side.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am here, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Heyday!

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Astonishment!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What is all this alarm and confusion? there is nothing but hurry in the house; what is the reason of it?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Because you have been in that chamber; have been! nay you are there at this moment, as these ladies have protested, so don't deny it—

sp.speaker: Traverse.
sp.p: This is the clearest Alibi I ever knew, Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Flower.
sp.p: Luce clarius.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Upon my word, ladies, if you have often these frolicks, it would be really entertaining to pass a whole summer with you. But come, [to Betty] open the door, and intreat your amiable mistress to come forth, and dispel all our doubts with her smiles.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [opening the door.] Madam, you are wanted in this room. [pertly.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: You see she's ready dress'd—and what confusion she's in!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Ready to pack off, bag and baggage!—her guilt confounds her!—

sp.speaker: Flowers.
sp.p: Silence in the court, ladies!

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I am confounded, indeed, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Don't droop, my beauteous lilly! but with your own peculiar modesty declare your state of mind.—Pour conviction into their ears, and raptures into mine. [smiling.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I am at this moment the most unhappy—most distrest—the tumult is too much for my heart—and I want the power to reveal a secret, which to conceal has been the misfortune and misery of my—my— [faints away.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: She faints; help, help! for the fairest, and best of women!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [running to her.] O my dear mistress!—help, help, there!—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha! let me fly to her assistance.

div2.stage: Lovewell rushes out from the chamber.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: My Fanny in danger! I can contain no longer.—Prudence were now a crime; all other cares are lost in this!—speak, speak, to me, my dearest Fanny!—let me but hear thy voice, open your eyes, and bless me with the smallest sign of life![during this speech they are all in amazement.

sp.speaker: Miss Sterl.
sp.p: Lovewell!—I am easy.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I am thunderstuck!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I am petrify'd!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And I undone!

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: [recovering.] O Lovewell!—even supported by thee, I dare not look my father nor his Lordship in the face.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What now! did not I send you to London, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Eh!—What!—How's this?—by what right and title have you been half the night in that lady's bed-chamber?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
