sp.p: By that right that makes me the happiest of men; and by a title which I would not forego, for any the best of kings could give me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I could cry my eyes out to hear his magnimity.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I am annihilated!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I have been choaked with rage and wonder; but now I can speak.—Zounds, what have you to say to me?—Lovewell, you are a villain.—You have broke your word with me.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, he has not—You forbad him to think of me, when it was out of his power to obey you; we have been married these four months.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: And he shan't stay in my house four hours. What baseness and treachery! As for you, you shall repent this step as long as you live, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, it is impossible to conceive the tortures I have already endured in consequence of my disobedience. My heart has continually upbraided me for it; and though I was too weak to struggle with affection, I feel that I must be miserable for ever without your forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Lovewell, you shall leave my house directly;—and you shall follow him, Madam. [to Fanny.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
And if they do, I will receive them into mine. Look ye, Mr. Sterling, there have been some
mistakes, which we had all better forget for our own sakes; and the best way to forget them is to forgive the cause of them; which I do from my soul.—Poor girl! I swore to support her affection with my life and fortune;—'tis a debt of honour, and must be paid—you swore as much too, Mr. Sterling; but your laws in the city will excuse you, I suppose; for you never strike a ballance without errors excepted.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I am a father, my Lord; but for the sake of all other fathers, I think I ought not to forgive her, for fear of encouraging other silly girls like herself to throw themselves away without the consent of their parents.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I hope there will be no danger of that, Sir. Young ladies with minds, like my Fanny's, would startle at the very shadow of vice; and when they know to what uneasiness only an indiscretion has exposed her, her example, instead, of encouraging, will rather serve to deter them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Indiscretion, quoth a! a mighty pretty delicat word to express disobedience!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: For my part, I indulge my own passions too much to tyrannize over those of other people. Poor souls, I pity them. And you must forgive them too. Come, come, melt a little of your flint, Mr. Sterling!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Why, why—as to that, my Lord—to be sure he is a relation of yours my Lord—what say you, sister Heidelberg?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: The girl's ruined, and I forgive her.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Well—so do I then.—Nay, no thanks— [to Lovewell and Fanny, who seem preparing to speak] there's an end of the matter.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: But, Lovewell, what makes you dumb all this while?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p:
Your kindness, my Lord—I can scarce believe my own senses—they are all in a tumult of fear, joy, love, expectation, and gratitude; I ever was, and am now more bound in duty to your Lordship;
for you, Mr. Sterling, if every moment of my life, spent gratefully in your service, will in some measure compensate the want of fortune, you perhaps will not repent your goodness to me. And you, ladies, I flatter myself, will not for the future suspect me of artifice and intrigue—I shall be happy to oblige, and serve you.—As for you, Sir John—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No apologies to me, Lovewell, I do not deserve any. All I have to offer in excuse for what has happened, is my total ignorance of your situation. Had you dealt a little more openly with me, you would have saved me, and yourself, and that lady, (who I hope will pardon my behaviour) a great deal of uneasiness. Give me leave, however, to assure you, that light and capricious as I may have appeared, now my infatuation is over, I have sensibility enough to be ashamed of the part I have acted, and honour enough to rejoice at your happiness.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And now, my dearest Fanny, though we are seemingly the happiest of beings, yet all our joys will be dampt, if his Lordship's generosity and Mr. Sterling's forgiveness should not be succeeded by the indulgence, approbation, and consent of these our best benefactors. [To the audience.

div2.head: SCENE an Assembly.
div2.stage: Several Persons at Cards, at different Tables; among the rest Col. Trill, Lord Minum, Mrs. Quaver, Sir Patrick Mahony.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: LADIES, with Leave—

sp.speaker: 2d Lady.
sp.l: Pass!

sp.speaker: 3d Lady.
sp.l: Pass!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Qu.
sp.l: You must do more.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Indeed I can't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Qu.
sp.l: I play in Hearts.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Encore▪

sp.speaker: 2d Lady.
sp.l: What Luck!

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: To-night at Drury-Lane is play'd
A Comedy, and toute nouvelle—a Spade!
Is not Miss Crotchet at the Play?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Qu.
sp.l: My Niece
Has made a Party, Sir, to damn the Piece.

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: I hate a Play-house—Trump!—It makes me sick.

sp.speaker: 1st Lady.
sp.l: We're two by Honours, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: And we the odd Trick.
Pray do you know the Author, Colonel Trill?

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: I know no Poets, Heaven be prais'd—Spadille!

sp.speaker: 1st Lady.
sp.l: I'll tell you who, my Lord!(whispers my Lord.)

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: What, he again?
" And dwell such daring Souls in little Men?"
Be whose it will, they down our Throats will cram it!

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: O, no.—I have a Club—the best.—We'll damn it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Qu.
sp.l: O Bravo, Colonel! Musick is my Flame.

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: And mine, by Jupiter!—We've won the Game.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: What, do you love all Musick?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Qu.
sp.l: No, not Handel's.
And nasty Plays—

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: Are fit for Goths and Vandals.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: Well, faith and troth! that Shakespeare was no Fool!

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: I'm glad you like him, Sir!—So ends the Pool!

lg.head: SONG by the Colonel.
lg.l: I hate all their Nonsense,
Their Shakespears and Johnsons,
Their Plays, and their Play-house, and Bards:
'Tis singing, not saying;
A Fig for all playing,
But playing, as we do, at Cards!
I love to see Jonas,
Am pleas'd too with Comus;
Each well the Spectator rewards.
So clever, so neat in
Their Tricks, and their Cheating!
Like them we would fain deal our Cards.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: King Lare is touching!—And how fine to see
Ould Hamlet's Ghost!—"To be, or not to be."—
What are your Op'ras to Othello's roar?
Oh, he's an Angel of a Blackamoor!

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: What, when he choaks his Wife?—

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: And calls her Whore?

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: King Richard calls his Horse—and then Macbeth,
When e'er he murders—takes away the Breath.
My Blood runs cold at ev'ry Syllable,
To see the Dagger—that's invisible. (All laugh.)

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: Laugh if you please, a pretty Play—

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: Is pretty.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: And when there's Wit in't—

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: To be sure 'tis witty.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: I love the Play-house now—so light and gay,
With all those Candles, they have ta'en away!(All laugh.)
For all your Game, what makes it so much brighter?

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Put out the Light, and then—

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: 'Tis so much lighter.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: Pray do you mane, Sirs, more than you express?

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Just as it happens—

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: Either more, or less.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Qu.
sp.l: An't you asham'd, Sir? [to Sir Pat.]

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: Me!—I seldom blush.—
For little Shakespeare, faith! I'd take a Push!

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: News, News!—here comes Miss Crotchet from the Play.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Qu.
sp.l: Well, Crotchet, what's the News?

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: We've lost the Day.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Tell us, dear Miss, all you have heard and seen.

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: I'm tir'd—a Chair—here, take my Capuchin!

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: And isn't it damn'd, Miss?

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: No, my Lord, not quite:
But we shall damn it.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: To-morrow Night.
There is a Party of us, all of Fashion,
Resolv'd to exterminate this vulgar Passion:
A Play-house, what a Place!—I must forswear it.
A little Mischief only makes one bear it.
Such Crowds of City Folks!—so rude and pressing!
And their Horse-Laughs, so hideously distressing!
When e'er we hiss'd, they frown'd and fell a swearing,
Like their own Guildhall Giants—fierce and staring!

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: What said the Folks of Fashion? were they cross?

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: The rest have no more Judgement than my Horse.

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: Lord Grimly swore 'twas execrable Stuff.
Says one, Why so, my Lord?—My Lord took Snuff.
In the first Act Lord George began to doze.
And criticis'd the Author—through his Nose;
So loud indeed, that as his Lordship snor'd,
The Pit turn'd round, and all the Brutes encor'd.
Some Lords, indeed, approv'd the Author's Jokes.

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: We have among us, Miss, some foolish Folks.

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: Says poor Lord Simper—Well, now to my Mind
The Piece is good;—but he's both deaf and blind.

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: Upon my Soul a very pretty Story!
And Quality appears in all its Glory!—
There was some Merit in the Piece, no Doubt;

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: O, to be sure!—if one could find it out.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: But tell us, Miss, the Subject of the Play.

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: Why, 'twas a Marriage—yes, a Marriage—Stay!
A Lord, an Aunt, two Sisters, and a Merchant—
A Baronet—ten Lawyers—a fat Serjeant—
Are all produc'd—to talk with one another;
And about something make a mighty Pother;
They all go in, and out; and to, and fro;
And talk, and quarrel—as they come and go—
Then go to Bed, and then get up—and then—
Scream, faint, scold, kiss,—and go to Bed again. [all laugh.
Such is the Play—Your Judgment! never sham it.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Oh damn it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Qu.
sp.l: Damn it!

sp.speaker: 1st Lady.
sp.l: Damn it!

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: Damn it!

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: Damn it!

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: Well, faith, you speak your Minds, and I'll be free—
Good Night! this Company's too good for me. [going.]

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Your Judgment, dear Sir Patrick, makes us proud. [all laugh.]

sp.speaker: Sir Pat.
sp.l: Laugh if you please, but pray don't laugh too loud. [Exit.]

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Now the Barbarian's gone, Miss, tune your Tongue,
And let us raise our Spirits high with Song!

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: Colonel, de tout mon Coeur—I've one in petto,
Which you shall join, and make it a Duetto.

sp.speaker: Ld. Min.
sp.l: Bella Signora, et Amico mio!
I too will join, and then we'll make a Trio.—

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Come all and join the full-mouth'd Chorus,
And drive all Tragedy and Comedy before us!

div2.stage: All the Company rise, and advance to the Front of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: Would you ever go to see a Tragedy?

sp.speaker: Miss Cro.
sp.l: Never, never.

sp.speaker: Col. T.
sp.l: A Comedy?

sp.speaker: Ld. M.
sp.l: Never, never,
Live for ever!
Tweedle-dum and Tweedle-dee!

sp.speaker: Col. T. Ld. M. and Miss Cro.
sp.l: Live for ever!
Tweedle-dum and Tweedle-dee!
Would you ever go to see, &c.
